Which is great for those who are disabled or LGBTQ+ that I can see myself using in 3-5 years. Or even in the next 6 months.
cons: The pay isn’t enough to hold you up on its own. I make $9 an hour even with the tips it’s hard to afford living. Starbucks is a part time company they focus on allowing you shorter shifts not to be overwhelmed because that can happen sometimes, but 20 hours or so a week can’t work for someone who needs to provided for themselves without another job. I wish that would change.

review_title: Starbucks is literally buying me college.
pros: They really do pay for college, and they pay for 100% of it. Management really care about their employees and making sure we are happy with our hours, scheduling, and that we have a good work/life balance. I have been with Starbucks for a little over three years and at this point everyone working at my store have conversations like ones between family. Even when we were shut down during Covid-19 they paid us for the hours we would have been scheduled and they continued our benefits. They did not fire people, but they had each of us choose between being released with the option to collect unemployment, taking an unpaid leave of absence, and staying on but keeping in mind that staffing and hours may go down due to decreased demand. Overall an incredible company to work for. And, who does not want free college?
cons: The business model is one in which the customer is our utmost priority. That said, some customers expect so much that we physically cannot fulfil their wants and they can get very upset about it.

pros: Free meal and free drinks... Which is expected in food service... Get a "markout" item as well.
cons:
The aforementioned "benefits" is the reason low wage is such an issue. You get up to I believe 3 free drinks (depending on how many hours) when you're working, unnecessary in my opinion. I'd rather be paid more for everything you're expected to do...

However the REAL issue is with how Starbucks trains its employees. I trained at a completely separate cafe from where I'd be working and only had 4 days of training. My 4th day I was what's called "live" and expected to be ready. I've never been with an employer that incorporates failing into their training. They WANT you to make mistakes and just learn on the fly, instead of properly educating and setting their staff up for success. This works well for some, but mix this with the high volume and unrealistic demands of bougie white Karen's at the mall... For $9 an hour, there just isn't enough compensation or training for what's expected of you. Great for ignorant kids that don't give a crap about cleaning, ticket times, etc. Highly disappointed ~

review_title: Good Company, Experience Ruined by COVID
pros:
-starting pay is decent, part-time benefits are a great relief
-tips can be really good
-coworkers are often really nice and supportive, easy to get along with
-good training
-work can be fun and engaging when slow enough
-a good team can make a shift feel like nothing
cons:
-tips are inconsistent week to week. My Average ~$1.10-$1.20/hr
-basic wage is ahead of the curve but not by enough for some areas
-some employees, incl. supervisors can be awful to work with
-expect to be shorthanded a lot
-expect to be multitasking all day. Laborious, frantic work.
-Your shift will almost never end on time.
-Some folks will


-Customer base is selfish, spiteful, aggressive, condescending, fussy, and overall maddeningly frustrating to work with. Expect to be corrected by customers on drinks that you have made a dozen times, or to be told you made it wrong on the vaguest grounds.
Customers will try to cheat you, scam you, and stretch every penny for a dollar. You will have them complain about how they come to your store every day and get the same drink but *you* somehow made it wrong.

All of this has been exacerbated and made worse by COVID. Anti-Maskers, massive orders, short supply, short-staffed, and corporate/upper-level management dragging their feet on anything to help their employees.

Can I recommend Starbucks? If I had joined several years ago, maybe. I know partners who have been with the company 10+ years, but after almost 2 years I am running out of rope. Right now, I can only halfheartedly say "Yes, BUT not as a full-time career".

I want to love my job. I USED to love my job.
